docs.lead_paragraph: How an unpopular Republican governor is fending off a primary challenge from a popular Republican senator who has the key players of the Bush administration behind her.
docs.snippet: How an unpopular Republican governor is fending off a primary challenge from a popular Republican senator who has the key players of the Bush administration behind her.

docs.lead_paragraph: STATISTICALLY, it was more difficult to land a job at the Applebee's restaurant that opened this summer at Fordham Plaza in the Bronx than it was to get into the freshman class that entered Harvard a few weeks later: more than 6,500 people applied for 120 jobs (the staff has since been whittled to about 80). Most work for tips or minimum wage, and have the opportunity to buy health insurance through the company's group plan. Applicants to the new Applebee's, one of 20 now open in New York City, included people with college degrees, people who had worked at high-end restaurants, people who had applied for dozens of other jobs -- perhaps not surprising in the Bronx, the county with the highest unemployment rate in the state, 13.4 percent. About a half-dozen of the new hires came from other Applebee's locations. ''In this economy,'' said Tim McKinley, a waiter, ''you walk out of your job every day with money in your pocket; that's a privilege.'' Here are a few of the lucky 1.8 percent who made it. SAM DOLNICK

headline.main: A Bar-and-Grill Chain Choosier Than the Ivy League

docs.lead_paragraph: Should health insurance companies cover prayer as a legitimate medical expense? The Christian Science church is seeking to insert a measure in the Senate's health care legislation that would encourage private insurance companies to cover prayer and spiritual treatment of the sick, even though both the House and Senate turned down earlier versions.

headline.main: To a Divisive Debate, Now Add Religion
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Christian Science religion is trying to insert measure into Senate version of health care legislation that would encourage private insurance companies to cover prayer and spiritual treatment of sick, even though both House and Senate turned down earlier versions; question of taxpayer support for alternative therapies and treatments not considered 'evidence based' has become another facet of health care debate; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS - Last Tuesday night, Jenny Potter and the rest of the gold-medal-winning 1998 United States Olympic women's hockey team were inducted into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame. Later this month, Potter is expected to be named to her fourth Olympic team when Coach Mark Johnson makes his final cuts.

headline.main: Family Loss Fills Potter's Olympic Season With Sadness

docs.abstract: Jenny Potter, on the verge of making her fourth U.S. Olympic women's hockey team, was dealt the double grief of the death of her mother and grandmother 11 days apart.
docs.snippet: Jenny Potter, on the verge of making her fourth U.S. Olympic women's hockey team, was dealt the double grief of the death of her mother and grandmother 11 days apart.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Senate clashing over health care legislation through the weekend, President Obama will head to Capitol Hill on Sunday afternoon to meet with the Democratic caucus in a session that aides at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue said was designed to galvanize lawmakers, even as they remain internally divided over many important issues.

headline.main: Obama to Capitol on Sunday to Rally Senators

docs.abstract: President Obama will head to Capitol Hill on Sunday to rally Democrats as lawmakers as the floor fight over major health care legislation continues through the weekend.
docs.snippet: President Obama will head to Capitol Hill on Sunday to rally Democrats as lawmakers as the floor fight over major health care legislation continues through the weekend.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and JEFF ZELENY

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Max Baucus was in a romantic relationship with a woman he nominated for United States attorney, a spokesman disclosed early Saturday morning. Mr. Baucus, a Democrat of Montana, and the woman, Melodee Hanes, were separated from their spouses at the time they became romantically involved in the summer of 2008, the spokesman said, and the two are still together.

headline.main: Saturday Word: Nominating From the Heart
